questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of difficulty swallowing solid food and liquids for 1 month. During the past 5 months, he has also had increased weakness of his hands and legs. He sails regularly and is unable to hold the ropes as tightly as before. Ten years ago, he was involved in a motor vehicle collision. Examination shows atrophy of the tongue. Muscle strength is decreased in the right upper and lower extremities. There is muscle stiffness in the left lower extremity. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in the right upper and lower extremities, 3+ in the left upper extremity, and 4+ in the left lower extremity. Plantar reflex shows an extensor response on the left foot. Sensation to light touch, pinprick, and vibration is intact. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis (MG) can manifest with generalized muscle weakness most commonly involving the extraocular or eyelid muscles that becomes worse with prolonged muscle activity. This patient's weakness is unrelated to activity and the presence of upper motor neuron signs and tongue atrophy are inconsistent with this diagnosis. Also, deep tendon reflexes are usually normal in patients with MG.

B) INCORRECT:

Syringomyelia can be caused by trauma such as this patient's motor vehicle collision, and it most commonly manifests with loss of pain and temperature sensation and flaccid paralysis in a typical cape-like distribution involving the neck, shoulders, and arms. Although expansion of the syrinx can compromise the pyramidal tract and cause upper motor neuron signs in the lower extremities, this would not explain the asymmetry of upper and lower motor neuron signs seen in the lower extremities of this patient. The presence of bulbar symptoms (dysphagia) and tongue atrophy, as well as the lack of sensory symptoms, suggest another diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) typically manifests between 50 and 70 years of age with progressively worsening features of both upper motor neuron degeneration (e.g., hyperreflexia, increased muscle tone, Babinski sign) and lower motor neuron degeneration (e.g., hyporeflexia, decreased muscle tone, atrophy), as seen in this patient. While dysphagia from bulbar atrophy is present in approx. 25% of patients at disease onset, it is most often a late clinical feature and suggests a poor prognosis.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

D) INCORRECT:

Inclusion-body myositis can manifest with slowly progressive weakness of both proximal and distal muscle groups. However, this patient also presents with signs of neurological involvement (increased muscle tone, changes in deep tendon reflexes, and a positive plantar reflex) that are inconsistent with this diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord can also manifest with muscle weakness, increased muscle tone, and a positive Babinski sign. However, this disease typically manifests symmetrically with decreased proprioception, vibratory sensation, and sensory ataxia from involvement of the dorsal columns. The presence of bulbar symptoms (dysphagia) and tongue atrophy, as well as the lack of sensory and proprioceptive findings, suggest another diagnosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Multifocal motor neuropathy (MMN) can manifest with lower motor neuron signs, such as flaccid paralysis and areflexia. However, the upper motor neuron is not affected in patients with MMN and, therefore, hyperreflexia, increased muscle tone, and Babinski sign would not be expected findings in this condition.

G) INCORRECT:

Cervical spondylosis with myelopathy can be elicited by trauma such as this patient's motor vehicle collision and can manifest with both upper and lower motor neuron signs. However, patients typically present with lower motor neuron signs (e.g., weakness, atrophy, and hyporeflexia) and sensory deficits at the level of the lesion, and can display signs of upper motor neuron degeneration (e.g., hyperreflexia, spasticity, and positive Babinski's sign) in the lower extremities, rather than the diffuse distribution seen in this patient. Additionally, dysphagia and tongue atrophy suggest cranial nerve involvement, which would be inconsistent with this diagnosis.
questions.hint: Medications used for the treatment of this patient's condition include riluzole and edaravone.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing weakness of his arms and legs over the past year. He has also had difficulty speaking for the past 5 months. He underwent a partial gastrectomy for gastric cancer 10 years ago. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mm Hg. Examination shows dysarthria. There is mild atrophy and twitching of the tongue. Muscle strength is decreased in all extremities. Muscle tone is decreased in the right lower extremity and increased in the other extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the right lower extremity and 4+ in the other extremities. Plantar reflex shows an extensor response on the left. Sensation is intact in all extremities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Given the history of partial gastrectomy, this patient is at risk of developing vitamin B12 deficiency, which may manifest with neurological deficits such as peripheral neuropathy or subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord. Peripheral neuropathy from vitamin B12 deficiency would result in paresthesias, and/or sensory loss, while subacute combined degeneration results in a combination of progressive UMN weakness in the lower limbs and symmetrical loss of vibration and proprioceptive sensations. Decreased muscle tone, muscle atrophy, fasciculations, and asymmetrically absent DTRs would not be an expected finding.

B) INCORRECT:

Nusinersen was approved by the FDA in 2016 to treat spinal muscular atrophy. Patients with spinal muscular atrophy may present with progressive weakness, hypotonia, and fasciculations of the tongue, without any sensory deficits. However, the onset of symptoms typically occurs during infancy and childhood, and patients present only with features of LMN lesions, in contrast to the mixed UMN and LMN weakness seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Glatiramer acetate is used in patients with multiple sclerosis. Multiple sclerosis may manifest with slowly progressive weakness. However, patients usually present with isolated UMN weakness, not the mixed UMN and LMN weakness seen here, and the clinical course of multiple sclerosis is characterized by periodic exacerbations and remissions. Moreover, nearly 80% of patients will have at least one of the following features in addition to weakness: sensory loss, paresthesias, optic neuritis, diplopia, or ataxia.

D) CORRECT:

While there is no definitive treatment for patients with ALS, riluzole can be used to slow down the deterioration of motor function and increase life expectancy by a few months. Edaravone, the other FDA-approved drug used in the management of ALS, has been shown to slow functional decline in some patients. Patients with ALS require multidisciplinary care, including physiotherapy, speech and occupational therapy, noninvasive ventilatory support, and specialized nutritional support via percutaneous gastrostomy, if indicated. The prognosis of ALS is generally very poor and most patients die within 3–5 years of symptom onset.

E) INCORRECT:

Pyridostigmine is the treatment of choice for patients with myasthenia gravis (MG), who typically present with limb weakness without sensory deficits. However, the clinical course of MG is characterized by muscle fatigue that worsens throughout the day and with increased activity, and improves with rest, unlike in this patient with progressively worsening symptoms. Smaller muscles responsible for fine movements (i.e., the eye muscles) tend to be affected first, while larger muscles become affected later. Also, proximal muscles are more commonly affected, DTRs would be normal, and most patients would have some degree of ptosis or external ophthalmoplegia.

F) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are used to treat acute exacerbations of demyelinating disorders such as multiple sclerosis (MS). Patients with MS usually present with isolated UMN weakness, in contrast to the mixed UMN and LMN weakness seen here, and the clinical course of MS is typically characterized by periodic exacerbations and remissions. Moreover, nearly 80% of patients will have at least one of the following features in addition to weakness: sensory loss, paresthesias, optic neuritis, diplopia, or ataxia.
questions.hint: This patient has clinical features of upper motor neuron (UMN) dysfunction, such as increased muscle tone, extensor plantar response, and increased deep tendon reflexes (DTRs), as well as lower motor neuron (LMN) dysfunction, such as decreased muscle tone, atrophy, fasciculations, and absent DTRs, which suggest amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man comes to the physician because of dysphagia and hoarseness of voice for the past 3 months. Initially, he had difficulty swallowing solid food but now has difficulty swallowing porridge and liquids as well. He has recently been choking on his oral secretions. During this period, he has had an 8.2-kg (18-lb) weight loss. He has noticed increasing weakness of both arms over the past year. He appears ill. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 74/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 114/74 mm Hg. Examination shows tongue atrophy and pooled oral secretions. There is diffuse muscle atrophy with occasional twitching. He is unable to lift his arms above the chest level. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ in all extremities. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration is intact. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
16.1 g/dL


Leukocyte count
10,900/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
15 mm/h


Serum



 Na+

136 mEq/L


 K+

4.2 mEq/L


 Cl-

101 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
12 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL


 Creatine kinase
320 U/L


 Albumin
4.3 mg/dL


An esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Destruction of upper and lower motor neurons
Dilation of the central spinal canal

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Destruction of upper motor neurons (UMNs) and lower motor neurons (LMNs) in multiple body segments (cranial, cervical, thoracic, and lumbosacral) is characteristic of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). UMN destruction results in increased muscle tone and spasticity, whereas LMN damage causes early muscle atrophy and fasciculations. This patient initially had neurological deficits in his cranial nerves (hoarseness, choking on secretions, dysphagia), which have recently progressed to other body segments (weakness, fasciculations, hyperreflexia). This progression from one to multiple affected segments is the typical disease course for ALS. Lab values in patients with ALS may show an elevation in creatine kinase but are otherwise normal. Although ALS is primarily a clinical diagnosis, this patient will likely need further diagnostic testing, including MRI and electromyography, as part of the standard evaluation for all motor neuron diseases.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

B) INCORRECT:

Dilation of the central spinal canal (i.e., syringomyelia) is a slowly progressive process that usually causes abnormal functioning of the spinothalamic fibers, which leads to loss of pain and temperature sensation in a dermatomal distribution (dissociated sensory loss). The fluid-filled cystic structure can eventually grow to involve the corticospinal tracts and anterior horn cells, which leads to weakness in the affected myotome. The dilation of the central spinal canal may also extend into the medulla (i.e., syringobulbia) and affect cranial nerves, which can manifest with tongue atrophy and dysphagia. However, syringomyelia typically also manifests with sensory loss, and it is not associated with hyperreflexia.

C) INCORRECT:

Demyelination of peripheral nerves can be caused by Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), which begins as muscle weakness in the lower extremities and rapidly progresses to involve the upper extremities and, in more severe cases, bulbar/facial muscles. Typically, these symptoms progress over the course of a few days, not months. GBS also causes hyporeflexia due to lower motor neuron (peripheral nerve) demyelination, not hyperreflexia. In addition, about two-thirds of patients with GBS report a preceding upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune destruction of acetylcholine receptors is seen in myasthenia gravis (MG). Individuals with MG usually have muscle weakness that is worse at the end of the day or during periods of activity. Though this patient also has muscle weakness, he has concurrent upper motor neuron signs (hyperreflexia), which are not seen in MG. In addition, more than 50% of patients with MG have ocular symptoms (ptosis and diplopia).

E) INCORRECT:

Multiple cerebral infarctions can be caused by embolic strokes, possibly leading to upper motor neuron (UMN) symptoms that involve the facial, upper and lower extremity muscles. This patient has UMN signs (hyperreflexia) in addition to muscle weakness, which can both occur following cerebral infarctions. However, he also has lower motor neuron signs (muscle atrophy and muscle twitching, i.e., fasciculations), which are not caused by strokes. Also, strokes typically result in asymmetric, instead of bilateral muscle weakness.
questions.hint: Stephen Hawking suffered from this disease.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of hoarseness and drooling. Initially, he had difficulty swallowing solid food, but now he has difficulty swallowing foods like oatmeal as well. During this period, he also developed weakness in both arms and has had an 8.2 kg (18 lb) weight loss. He appears ill. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows tongue atrophy and pooled oral secretions. There is mild spasticity in all extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ in all extremities. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration is intact. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Destruction of upper and lower motor neurons
Dilation of the central spinal canal

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Multiple cerebral infarctions would be characteristic of embolic strokes and would cause upper motor neuron symptoms such as hypereflexia and spasticity in the extremities, and dysphagia (due to pseudobulbar palsy). Tongue atrophy indicates that this patient has bulbar palsy (a lower motor neuron sign) rather than pseudobulbar palsy.

B) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune destruction of acetylcholine receptors is seen in myasthenia gravis. Individuals with MG usually have muscle weakness that is worse at the end of the day or during periods of activity. Although this patient also has muscle weakness, he has signs of UMN involvement (hyperreflexia), which are not seen in MG. In addition, more than 50% of patients with MG have ocular symptoms (ptosis and diplopia).

C) INCORRECT:

Peripheral nerve demyelination is the mechanism of Guillain-Barre syndrome, which classically manifests with ascending weakness and can also involve the bulbar and facial muscles. However, it typically presents over the course of a few days, rather than the months seen in this patient. GBS also causes hyporeflexia due to lower motor neuron demyelination, not hyperreflexia, as seen here. In addition, about two-thirds of patients with GBS report a preceding upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection.

D) CORRECT:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is characterized by the progressive destruction of upper motor neurons (UMNs) in the precentral gyrus and prefrontal cortex and lower motor neurons (LMNs) in the anterior horn of the spinal cord and brainstem. Patients with ALS therefore develop a mix of both UMN and LMN signs. UMN damage is responsible for hyperreflexia and spasticity in this patient's extremities. Bulbar palsy due to LMN damage has caused this patient's dysphagia and tongue atrophy. Sensory function is unaffected in patients with ALS.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

E) INCORRECT:

Dilation of the central spinal canal is characteristic of syringomyelia, which can cause lower motor neuron signs at the level of the syrinx and upper motor neuron signs below the level of the syrinx. However, syringomyelia causes progressive damage to the spinothalamic tract and manifests with dermatomal loss of pain and temperature sensation (dissociated sensory loss).
questions.hint: Medications such as riluzole and edaravone can slow functional decline in patients with this condition.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of 6 months of progressive weakness in her arms and legs. During this time, she has also had difficulty swallowing and holding her head up. Examination shows pooling of oral secretions. Muscle strength and tone are decreased in the upper extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in the right upper and lower extremities, 3+ in the left upper extremity, and 4+ in the left lower extremity. Sensation to light touch, pinprick, and vibration are intact. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) typically presents between 50–70 years of age with progressively worsening features of both upper motor neuron damage (hyperreflexia, increased muscle tone, Babinski sign) and lower motor neuron damage (hyporeflexia, decreased muscle tone, atrophy), as seen in this patient. While dysphagia from bulbar atrophy is present in approximately 25% of patients at disease onset, it is most often a late clinical feature and suggests a poor prognosis.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

B) INCORRECT:

Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) can manifest with weakness in the upper and lower extremities, as seen in this patient. However, it usually begins with back pain (due to nerve root inflammation) and rapidly progressive symmetric ascending paresis in the legs after a recent infection (e.g. Campylobacter jejuni and CMV). Moreover, GBS is associated with symmetric hyporeflexia (not hyperreflexia) due to damage of Schwann cells, which impairs signal transduction in peripheral nerves. Additionally, it usually manifests with peripheral symmetric paresthesias, in contrast to this patient's normal sensory exam.

C) INCORRECT:

Syringomyelia can result from an inborn defect or be caused by trauma (e.g. motor vehicle collision). It most commonly presents with loss of pain and temperature sensation, unlike in this patient, and flaccid paralysis in a typical cape-like distribution involving the neck, shoulders, and arms. The presence of bulbar symptoms (dysphagia), hyperreflexia, and the lack of sensory symptoms suggest another diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis (MG) can present with generalized muscle weakness most commonly involving the extraocular or eyelid muscles that becomes worse with prolonged muscle activity. This patient's weakness is unrelated to activity and the presence of upper/lower motor neuron signs is inconsistent with this diagnosis. Also, deep tendon reflexes are usually normal in patients with MG.

E) INCORRECT:

Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) can manifest with weakness in the upper and lower extremities, as seen in this patient, due to degeneration of anterior horn cells. It also causes bulbar symptoms, while sensations are preserved. In contrast to this patient's asymmetric neurological findings, patients with SMA usually present with symmetric diffuse proximal muscle weakness that is more pronounced in the lower extremities, and hyporeflexia, not hyperreflexia. Moreover, SMA rarely manifests in late adulthood.
questions.hint: This patient's progressive weakness, upper motor neuron signs (e.g., hyperreflexia), and lower motor neuron signs (e.g., muscle weakness and decreased muscle tone), and intact sensation is consistent with a condition caused by selective degeneration of motor fibers.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a 1-year history of recurrent aspiration pneumonia is brought to the emergency department by his daughter after being found unconscious and gasping for air in his bed. Despite resuscitative efforts, the patient dies. Autopsy of the patient shows degeneration of the corticospinal tracts and anterior horn cells of the upper cervical cord. There is asymmetrical atrophy of the limb muscles, the diaphragm, and the intercostal muscles. Which of the following drugs would have most likely slowed the progression of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Levodopa is used in the treatment of Parkinson disease, which can present with asymmetrical muscle atrophy. However, in Parkinson disease, autopsy would show neuron degeneration of the substantia nigra, not of the corticospinal tracts and anterior horn cells of the upper cervical cord. Moreover, respiratory failure is rare in Parkinson disease.
Image Description:

Dopamine agonists (e.g., ropinirole, bromocriptine) bind to the dopamine receptor, mimicking the action of dopamine.

DOPA-Decarboxylase (DDC) inhibitors (e.g., carbidopa) decrease the peripheral conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine, which results in reduced peripheral side-effects of L-DOPA. These drugs cannot cross the blood-brain barrier and therefore do not reduce dopamine production in the brain nor do they have central side-effects.

Dopamine precursors (e.g., L-DOPA) are converted by DOPA decarboxylase at the presynaptic neuron resulting in direct dopaminergic effects (especially in D2 receptors).

COMT inhibitors (e.g., entacapone, tolcapone) inhibits central (tolcapone) or peripheral (entacapone) catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) resulting in the reduced metabolization of dopamine, increase in dopamine effects, a decreased demand for L-DOPA, and a longer therapeutic effect with each dose.

MAO-B inhibitors (e.g., selegiline) reduce the metabolism of central dopamine by inhibiting the monoamine oxidase B enzyme, which normally breaks down dopamine (and catecholamines) in the brain. This results in a prolonged dopamine effect and reduced demand for L-DOPA.

Anticholinergic drugs (e.g., benztropine) inhibit excitatory cholinergic neurons, resulting in a proportionately lower concentration of acetylcholine compared to dopamine.

NMDA antagonists (e.g., amantadine) act as antagonists at the glutamate N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor, which results in a dopaminergic effect.

B) INCORRECT:

Nusinersen is used to treat spinal muscular atrophy, which presents with motor weakness (also intercostal muscle weakness, which can lead to respiratory failure) due to apoptosis of lower motor neurons (especially the anterior horn cells in the spinal cord), as seen in this patient. However, muscle atrophy would usually be symmetrical, not asymmetrical, and the onset of symptoms in spinal muscular atrophy typically occurs during infancy or childhood, not in late adulthood.

C) INCORRECT:

Glatiramer acetate is used in the treatment of patients with multiple sclerosis, a demyelinating disease that can cause upper motor neuron weakness and subsequent respiratory failure. However, autopsy would show focal demyelination, loss of axons, and atrophy of oligodendrocytes (plaques) that more likely involve the dorsal spinal column, causing sensory impairment (e.g., numbness, paresthesia), than the corticospinal tracts and anterior horn cells. Moreover, asymmetrical atrophy of the limb muscles would not be found in patients with MS.

D) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are used to treat chronic, inflammatory diseases like systemic sclerosis, which can present with esophageal hypomotility (gastroesophageal reflux and aspiration pneumonia) and respiratory disease (and possible respiratory failure) due to abnormal growth of connective tissue, leading to diffuse thickening and hardening of the skin and inner organs. Symptoms would also include cutaneous findings (e.g, thickening and hardening of the skin, sclerodactyly, calcinosis, Raynaud syndrome, telangiectasia) but no motor weakness or muscle atrophy. In addition, autopsy would show fibroblast proliferation and increased synthesis of normal collagen (inflammatory synthesis of extracellular matrix) but no alpha motoneuron degeneration.

E) INCORRECT:

Inactivated virus vaccines are used in the pre-exposure prophylaxis of certain viral infections, such as poliomyelitis or rabies. Polio causes motor weakness and atrophy due to neuron degeneration of the spinal cord (particularly the anterior horn cells). Symptoms can be severe and involve the diaphragm, causing respiratory failure, but would also involve fever, neck stiffness, vomiting, and muscle pain. In addition, polio is extremely rare since it has been eradicated from the U.S. and most other countries. Rabies usually presents first with flu-like symptoms and then progresses to encephalopathy, which can lead to respiratory failure if the respiratory center in the brainstem is involved. However, other symptoms would include hydrophobia, agitation, confusion, hallucinations, seizures, muscle rigidity, and hypersalivation. Autopsy would show Negri bodies in the brain, not alpha motoneuron degeneration.

F) CORRECT:

ALS usually manifests in patients > 50 years old with a combination of symptoms of upper and lower motor neuron degeneration, including asymmetric limb weakness, fasciculations, cramps, and muscle stiffness. Symptoms of bulbar palsy, such as dysarthria as well as atrophy and fasciculations of the tongue, are early features of ALS in 25% of patients. Late symptoms include cognitive impairment as well as life-threatening conditions such as respiratory failure due to respiratory muscle paralysis and aspiration pneumonia due to bulbar weakness.

There is no definitive treatment for ALS. By blocking sodium channels, riluzole inhibits the excitotoxic effects of glutamate in the CNS and this effect slows down the deterioration of motor function in patients with ALS and thus increases life expectancy. Another medication used to slow the progression of ALS is edaravone (a free radical scavenger). The prognosis is generally very poor and most patients die within 3–5 years of symptom onset.
questions.hint: The autopsy findings of upper (corticospinal tract) and lower motor neuron (anterior horn cells, muscle atrophy) degeneration indicate amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive weakness in his upper extremities over the past 7 months. He initially noticed difficulty writing but now has difficulty performing his activities of daily living. He currently lives with his son. He has no personal or family history of serious illness and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is mild atrophy and twitching of the tongue. Muscle strength is decreased in the upper extremities and normal in the lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the upper extremities, 4+ in the right lower extremity, and 2+ in the left lower extremity. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration is intact in all extremities. On mental status examination, he is cooperative with a mildly anxious mood and a neutral affect. His speech is slightly slurred and hypernasal. Needle electromyography shows spontaneous fasciculation potentials in multiple muscles, fibrillations, and positive sharp wave potentials. Spirometry shows an FVC of 85% of predicted. A diagnosis of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is made and treatment with riluzole is initiated. After discussion with the patient and his son, a decision to transfer the patient to hospice care is made. Before transferring the patient to hospice care, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Noninvasive ventilation is indicated in patients with ALS with respiratory failure (e.g., orthopnea, vital capacity < 50%). This patient does not have symptoms of respiratory insufficiency (e.g., tachypnea, hypoxemia).

B) INCORRECT:

Genetic testing for specific ALS-causing mutations is useful in identifying familial ALS, which accounts for up to 10% of all ALS cases. Genetic testing is indicated in patients with a family history of ALS or juvenile-onset ALS, neither of which have been reported here.

C) INCORRECT:

Amitriptyline can be used to treat patients with ALS who present with features of depression or pseudobulbar affect. This patient does not have symptoms of depression and mental status examination shows a normal affect.

D) CORRECT:

ALS is characterized by concomitant upper motor neuron and lower motor neuron dysfunction and can manifest with pseudobulbar palsy and bulbar palsy, both of which result in dysphagia. Dysphagia increases the risk for aspiration and/or insufficient fluid and food intake, leading to complications in patients with ALS (e.g., aspiration pneumonia, weight loss). A bedside swallowing test should therefore be performed in all patients with ALS to screen for dysphagia. If the test is positive, a formal swallowing study (e.g., videofluoroscopic swallowing examination) is required to confirm the diagnosis. Patients with ALS who have swallowing difficulties may need specialized nutritional support (e.g., pureed food, thickened liquids, nasogastric tube, percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy). Bedside swallowing test is also performed for other neurological conditions that manifest with dysphagia, such as Parkinson disease, acute stroke, and Guillain-Barré syndrome.

In addition to the bedside swallowing test, this patient should be asked about their wishes regarding resuscitation. ALS can result in cognitive impairment in the later stages, and the patient's resuscitation wishes (e.g., do not resuscitate order) should be determined while their mental faculties are intact.

E) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy is indicated in patients with ALS who have symptomatic dysphagia or significant weight loss, none of which are seen here.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features of bulbar palsy (e.g., tongue atrophy and fasciculations, dysarthria, hypernasal speech) as a manifestation of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Bulbar palsy can cause a symptom that increases the morbidity of patients with ALS and should therefore be assessed.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of frequent falls and difficulty swallowing. He used to go for long walks with his wife but stopped because he could not lift his right leg properly. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Muscle strength is 2/5 on extension of the right knee and flexion of the right hip. Patellar and ankle reflexes are 1+ on the right leg and 3+ on the left leg. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration is intact. Cranial nerve examination shows an exaggerated gag reflex and fasciculations of the tongue. Mental status examination shows a labile affect and monotonous nasal speech. Results of screening laboratory studies, including a complete blood count, serum electrolyte concentrations, and creatine kinase, are within the reference ranges. Needle electromyography discloses spontaneous fasciculation potentials in multiple muscles. Nerve conduction studies are normal. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ascending paralysis is one of the hallmarks of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), which is characterized by rapidly progressive demyelination of the peripheral nerves and consequent LMN dysfunction. Although this patient has findings of LMN damage, he also shows signs of UMN damage, which would not be seen in GBS. Furthermore, muscle weakness in patients with GBS develops acutely (within days), typically is symmetric and progresses upward, and nerve conduction studies typically reveal a decrease in nerve conduction velocity, none of which is seen here. Finally, GBS symptoms usually occur after an episode of upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection and peak at 2–4 weeks after onset, neither of which is consistent with this patient's presentation.

B) INCORRECT:

Myasthenic crisis is an acute life-threatening complication of myasthenia gravis (MG), which is characterized by generalized muscle weakness that worsens throughout the day and during physical activity. Although this patient presents with muscular weakness, he has concurrent UMN signs, which are inconsistent with MG. In addition, EMG in patients with MG typically shows a decremental response following repetitive stimulation, whereas this patient's EMG shows spontaneous fasciculations. Finally, weakness in MG typically involves ocular muscles, manifesting with symptoms such as ptosis, diplopia, or blurred vision, none of which is reported by this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Cervical myelopathy is a common complication of cervical spine compression (e.g., in spondylosis, rheumatoid arthritis), which is characterized by findings of LMN injury at the level of the lesion and findings of UMN injury below the level of the lesion. Although this patient's hyperactive patellar and ankle reflexes are consistent with a cervical lesion, his upper extremities are not affected. Moreover, the presence of pseudobulbar palsy (monotonous nasal speech, exaggerated gag reflex, labile effect) and bulbar signs (tongue fasciculations) suggests the involvement of cranial nerves IX, X, and XII, which are not affected by cervical compression.

D) INCORRECT:

Internuclear ophthalmoplegia can be seen in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS), which may manifest with slowly progressive weakness and hyperreflexia, both of which are seen in this patient. However, MS is characterized by isolated UMN dysfunction, not the mixed UMN and LMN dysfunction seen here. This patient's presentation is consistent with ALS, which is not associated with internuclear ophthalmoplegia.

E) CORRECT:

This patient with ALS is at an increased risk for developing diaphragmatic paralysis and respiratory failure, which is the most common cause of death in individuals with ALS and requires prompt intervention. Noninvasive ventilation is the mainstay of management in patients with ALS and respiratory failure because it successfully compensates for the diaphragmatic dysfunction, provides symptomatic relief, improves quality of life, and increases survival rates. Disease-modifying drugs, such as riluzole and edaravone, should also be considered because they can slow down the functional decline and prolong survival in patients with ALS. Another severe complication of ALS is dysphagia, which can result in malnutrition, weight loss, and aspiration pneumonia and may require enteral nutrition support.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.
questions.hint: This patient presents with progressive asymmetric muscle weakness and signs of both upper motor neuron (UMN) dysfunction (hyperreflexia, pseudobulbar palsy) and lower motor neuron (LMN) dysfunction (hyporeflexia, bulbar palsy). These findings, in conjunction with spontaneous fasciculation potentials on electromyography (EMG), are consistent with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of progressive weakness in his left hand. He used to be completely independent but now needs his wife's help for tasks such as buttoning his shirt and opening the zipper of his pants. His wife has become increasingly frustrated with him and has to frequently remind him to speak more clearly because he is otherwise hard to understand. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He is alert and fully oriented. He is 186 cm (6 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 66 kg (145 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows decreased muscle strength in the left upper extremity and normal muscle strength in the right upper extremity. There is muscle atrophy of the left forearm most pronounced in the lateral and medial intrinsic muscles of the left hand with sparing of the little finger. Fasciculations are present in the left deltoid, left biceps, and right quadriceps femoris muscle. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the left upper extremity, 2+ in the right upper extremity, and 3+ in the lower extremities. Cranial nerve examination shows an exaggerated jaw jerk reflex. Sensation to light touch, pinprick, and vibration is intact. Mental status examination shows slow and labored speech. Which of the following is most likely to establish this patient's diagnosis?

choices.text: MRI of the brain and cervical spine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sensory and motor nerve conduction studies are a part of the diagnostic workup of ALS to rule out differential diagnoses such as multifocal motor neuropathy (MMN). Key features of MMN include asymmetric paralysis of upper limbs without associated sensory loss and areflexia. However, upper motor neuron involvement (pseudobulbar palsy, hyperreflexia) is inconsistent with MMN. In ALS, which this patient likely has, nerve conduction studies are usually normal.

B) INCORRECT:

Riluzole can slow the deterioration of motor function in patients with ALS and prolongs survival by a few months. Administration of riluzole may be appropriate in this patient once a diagnosis of ALS has been established, but it is not used to confirm the diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Muscle biopsy is not routinely used in the diagnostic evaluation of ALS. This diagnostic procedure is indicated in inflammatory myopathies (e.g., polymyositis, dermatomyositis), which can manifest with progressive muscle weakness, atrophy, and dysphagia. However, upper motor neuron involvement (pseudobulbar palsy, hyperreflexia) is inconsistent with inflammatory myopathies. ALS cannot be diagnosed with a muscle biopsy.

D) INCORRECT:

MRI of the brain and cervical spine is a part of the diagnostic workup of ALS to rule out differential diagnoses such as degenerative cervical spondylosis (DCS), which typically manifests with a combination of UMN and LMN dysfunction. However, characteristic features of DCS involve sensory abnormalities (e.g., paresthesia) at the level of the affected dermatome. Furthermore, findings of lower motor neuron injury are confined to the level of the lesion (e.g., hyporeflexia in the upper extremities), and findings of UMN injury are seen below the level of the lesion (e.g., hyperreflexia in the lower extremities, Babinski sign). In ALS, MRI findings are usually normal.

E) CORRECT:

ALS typically manifests between 50 and 70 years of age with symptoms due to progressive destruction of upper motor neurons (UMN) and lower motor neurons (LMN) in multiple body segments, as seen in this patient. Although ALS is primarily diagnosed clinically, patients with progressively worsening features of UMN and LMN degeneration should undergo electromyography (EMG) to confirm the diagnosis. EMG findings in ALS include spontaneous fasciculation potentials, which reflect the random firing of denervated motor units, and fibrillations and positive sharp wave potentials, which reflect the activity of denervated muscle fibers at rest. Although EMG abnormalities are not pathognomonic for ALS, a diagnosis is confirmed if there is evidence of UMN and LMN signs in ≥ 3 regions in conjunction with clinical findings.

Because the diagnosis of ALS requires the exclusion of alternative diagnoses, an MRI of the brain and cervical spine, laboratory studies, and nerve conduction studies should also be performed. Nerve conduction studies and brain MRI are usually normal in patients with ALS.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.
questions.hint: This patient with asymmetrical muscle weakness and dysarthria has signs of upper motor neuron (UMN) dysfunction (pseudobulbar palsy, hyperreflexia) and lower motor neuron (LMN) dysfunction (hyporeflexia, decreased muscle strength, fasciculations, and atrophy of intrinsic hand muscles with split hand sign). In conjunction with intact sensation, his presentation raises suspicion for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

questions.text:
A 53-year-old man reports progressive limb weakness. Approximately one year ago, he started tripping over his right foot, eventually progressing to difficulty standing from a chair. For the past 2 months, he has had weakness in his left leg and difficulty opening jars.
Physical examination reveals limb weakness and atrophy, most notably in the right leg but also involving distal muscles of the left leg and right arm. The patient also has hyperreflexia in both the upper and lower limbs and a Babinski sign bilaterally.
Mental status, cranial nerve, cerebellar, and sensory examinations are normal.
Which one of the following tests would be the best next step in establishing a diagnosis for this patient?

choices.text: Heavy metal screen and paraneoplastic panel

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is defined clinically by progressive weakness and physical examination findings of upper and lower motor-neuron degeneration affecting the bulbar, cervical, thoracic, and/or innervated lumbosacral muscles; there are no abnormal sensory findings. An electromyogram (EMG) and nerve-conduction study can reveal lower motor-neuron involvement (acute and chronic denervation). An EMG can also exclude demyelination or sensory-nerve involvement characteristic of other disorders that can mimic ALS.

Laboratory testing of parathyroid hormone, thyroid function, and creatine kinase is useful to rule out endocrine and primary muscle diseases but is typically low yield in the setting of an EMG consistent with the diagnosis. Additional diagnostic tests can exclude alternative diagnoses in specific situations.

Key learning point: The most appropriate first diagnostic test in a patient with suspected amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is an electromyogram/nerve-conduction study.

B) INCORRECT:

Heavy metal screens are no longer part of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis evaluation protocol in the United States, and paraneoplastic motor-neuron disease is very rare and limited to lower motor-neuron involvement.

C) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture can help exclude inflammatory, neoplastic, or infectious conditions but is not necessary unless one of these conditions is suspected.

D) INCORRECT:

A muscle biopsy may be warranted in a patient in whom a myopathy is suspected, but it is not a routine part of the workup for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. In this case, the patient has upper motor-neuron signs, which are not seen in a myopathy. If myopathic units are noted on the electromyogram, then a biopsy may be appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

MRI of the brain is often obtained as part of the workup of suspected amyotrophic lateral sclerosis to ensure that there are no underlying structural lesions that could cause weakness. However, an MRI of the brain does not establish the diagnosis; an electromyogram is required to do so.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is brought to the office because of 6 months of progressive weakness in her arms and legs. During this time, she has also had difficulty swallowing and holding her head up. Examination shows pooling of oral secretions. Muscle strength and tone are decreased in the upper extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ in the left lower extremity. Sensation to light touch, pinprick, and vibration are intact. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) typically presents between 50–70 years of age with progressively worsening features of both upper motor neuron damage (hyperreflexia, increased muscle tone, Babinski sign) and lower motor neuron damage (decreased muscle tone, atrophy), as seen in this patient. While dysphagia from bulbar atrophy is present in approximately 25% of patients at disease onset, it is most often a late clinical feature and suggests a poor prognosis.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

B) INCORRECT:

Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) can manifest with weakness in the upper and lower extremities, as seen in this patient. However, it usually begins with back pain (due to nerve root inflammation) and rapidly progressive symmetric ascending paresis in the legs after a recent infection (e.g. Campylobacter jejuni and CMV). Moreover, GBS is associated with symmetric hyporeflexia (not hyperreflexia) due to damage of Schwann cells, which impairs signal transduction in peripheral nerves. Additionally, it usually manifests with peripheral symmetric paresthesias, in contrast to this patient's normal sensory exam.

C) INCORRECT:

Syringomyelia can result from an inborn defect or be caused by trauma (e.g. motor vehicle collision). It most commonly presents with loss of pain and temperature sensation, unlike in this patient, and flaccid paralysis in a typical cape-like distribution involving the neck, shoulders, and arms. The presence of bulbar symptoms (dysphagia), hyperreflexia, and the lack of sensory symptoms suggest another diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis (MG) can present with generalized muscle weakness most commonly involving the extraocular or eyelid muscles that becomes worse with prolonged muscle activity. This patient's weakness is unrelated to activity and the presence of upper/lower motor neuron signs is inconsistent with this diagnosis. Also, deep tendon reflexes are usually normal in patients with MG.

E) INCORRECT:

Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) can manifest with weakness in the upper and lower extremities, as seen in this patient, due to degeneration of anterior horn cells. It also causes bulbar symptoms, while sensations are preserved. In contrast to this patient's asymmetric neurological findings, patients with SMA usually present with symmetric diffuse proximal muscle weakness that is more pronounced in the lower extremities, and hyporeflexia, not hyperreflexia. Moreover, SMA rarely manifests in late adulthood.
questions.hint: This patient's progressive weakness, upper motor neuron signs (e.g., hyperreflexia), and lower motor neuron signs (e.g., muscle weakness and decreased muscle tone), and intact sensation is consistent with a condition caused by selective degeneration of motor fibers.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a 1-year history of recurrent aspiration pneumonia is brought to the emergency department by his daughter after being found unconscious and gasping for air in his bed. Despite resuscitative efforts, the patient dies. Autopsy of the patient shows degeneration of the corticospinal tracts and anterior horn cells of the upper cervical cord. There is asymmetrical atrophy of the limb muscles, the diaphragm, and the intercostal muscles. Which of the following drugs would have most likely slowed the progression of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Levodopa is used in the treatment of Parkinson disease, which can present with asymmetrical muscle atrophy. However, in Parkinson disease, autopsy would show neuron degeneration of the substantia nigra, not of the corticospinal tracts and anterior horn cells of the upper cervical cord. Moreover, respiratory failure is rare in Parkinson disease.
Image Description:

Dopamine agonists (e.g., ropinirole, bromocriptine) bind to the dopamine receptor, mimicking the action of dopamine.

DOPA-Decarboxylase (DDC) inhibitors (e.g., carbidopa) decrease the peripheral conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine, which results in reduced peripheral side-effects of L-DOPA. These drugs cannot cross the blood-brain barrier and therefore do not reduce dopamine production in the brain nor do they have central side-effects.

Dopamine precursors (e.g., L-DOPA) are converted by DOPA decarboxylase at the presynaptic neuron resulting in direct dopaminergic effects (especially in D2 receptors).

COMT inhibitors (e.g., entacapone, tolcapone) inhibits central (tolcapone) or peripheral (entacapone) catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) resulting in the reduced metabolization of dopamine, increase in dopamine effects, a decreased demand for L-DOPA, and a longer therapeutic effect with each dose.

MAO-B inhibitors (e.g., selegiline) reduce the metabolism of central dopamine by inhibiting the monoamine oxidase B enzyme, which normally breaks down dopamine (and catecholamines) in the brain. This results in a prolonged dopamine effect and reduced demand for L-DOPA.

Anticholinergic drugs (e.g., benztropine) inhibit excitatory cholinergic neurons, resulting in a proportionately lower concentration of acetylcholine compared to dopamine.

NMDA antagonists (e.g., amantadine) act as antagonists at the glutamate N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor, which results in a dopaminergic effect.

B) INCORRECT:

Glatiramer acetate is used in the treatment of patients with multiple sclerosis, a demyelinating disease that can cause upper motor neuron weakness and subsequent respiratory failure. However, autopsy would show focal demyelination, loss of axons, and atrophy of oligodendrocytes (plaques) that more likely involve the dorsal spinal column, causing sensory impairment (e.g., numbness, paresthesia), than the corticospinal tracts and anterior horn cells. Moreover, asymmetrical atrophy of the limb muscles would not be found in patients with MS.

C) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are used to treat chronic, inflammatory diseases like systemic sclerosis, which can present with esophageal hypomotility (gastroesophageal reflux and aspiration pneumonia) and respiratory disease (and possible respiratory failure) due to abnormal growth of connective tissue, leading to diffuse thickening and hardening of the skin and inner organs. Symptoms would also include cutaneous findings (e.g, thickening and hardening of the skin, sclerodactyly, calcinosis, Raynaud syndrome, telangiectasia) but no motor weakness or muscle atrophy. In addition, autopsy would show fibroblast proliferation and increased synthesis of normal collagen (inflammatory synthesis of extracellular matrix) but no alpha motoneuron degeneration.

D) INCORRECT:

Inactivated virus vaccines are used in the pre-exposure prophylaxis of certain viral infections, such as poliomyelitis or rabies. Polio causes motor weakness and atrophy due to neuron degeneration of the spinal cord (particularly the anterior horn cells). Symptoms can be severe and involve the diaphragm, causing respiratory failure, but would also involve fever, neck stiffness, vomiting, and muscle pain. In addition, polio is extremely rare since it has been eradicated from the U.S. and most other countries. Rabies usually presents first with flu-like symptoms and then progresses to encephalopathy, which can lead to respiratory failure if the respiratory center in the brainstem is involved. However, other symptoms would include hydrophobia, agitation, confusion, hallucinations, seizures, muscle rigidity, and hypersalivation. Autopsy would show Negri bodies in the brain, not alpha motoneuron degeneration.

E) CORRECT:

ALS usually manifests in patients > 50 years old with a combination of symptoms of upper and lower motor neuron degeneration, including asymmetric limb weakness, fasciculations, cramps, and muscle stiffness. Symptoms of bulbar palsy, such as dysarthria as well as atrophy and fasciculations of the tongue, are early features of ALS in 25% of patients. Late symptoms include cognitive impairment as well as life-threatening conditions such as respiratory failure due to respiratory muscle paralysis and aspiration pneumonia due to bulbar weakness.

There is no definitive treatment for ALS. By blocking sodium channels, riluzole inhibits the excitotoxic effects of glutamate in the CNS and this effect slows down the deterioration of motor function in patients with ALS and thus increases life expectancy. Another medication used to slow the progression of ALS is edaravone (a free radical scavenger). The prognosis is generally very poor and most patients die within 3–5 years of symptom onset.
questions.hint: The autopsy findings of upper (corticospinal tract) and lower motor neuron (anterior horn cells, muscle atrophy) degeneration indicate amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the office because of a 3-month history of frequent falls and difficulty swallowing. Muscle strength is 2/5 in the right lower extremity. Patellar and ankle reflexes are 1+ on the right leg and 3+ on the left leg. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration is intact. Cranial nerve examination shows fasciculations of the tongue. Mental status examination shows a labile affect and monotonous nasal speech. Needle electromyography discloses spontaneous fasciculation potentials in multiple muscles. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ascending paralysis is one of the hallmarks of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), which is characterized by rapidly progressive demyelination of the peripheral nerves and consequent LMN dysfunction. Although this patient has findings of LMN damage, he also shows signs of UMN damage, which would not be seen in GBS. Furthermore, muscle weakness in patients with GBS develops acutely (within days) and typically is symmetric and progresses upward, none of which is seen here. Finally, GBS symptoms usually occur after an episode of upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection and peak at 2–4 weeks after onset, neither of which is consistent with this patient's presentation.

B) INCORRECT:

Myasthenic crisis is an acute life-threatening complication of myasthenia gravis (MG), which is characterized by generalized muscle weakness that worsens throughout the day and during physical activity. Although this patient presents with muscular weakness, he has concurrent UMN signs, which are inconsistent with MG. In addition, EMG in patients with MG typically shows a decremental response following repetitive stimulation, whereas this patient's EMG shows spontaneous fasciculations. Finally, weakness in MG typically involves ocular muscles, manifesting with symptoms such as ptosis, diplopia, or blurred vision, none of which is reported by this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Cervical myelopathy is a common complication of cervical spine compression (e.g., in spondylosis, rheumatoid arthritis), which is characterized by findings of LMN injury at the level of the lesion and findings of UMN injury below the level of the lesion. Although this patient's hyperactive patellar and ankle reflexes are consistent with a cervical lesion, his upper extremities are not affected. Moreover, the presence of pseudobulbar palsy (monotonous nasal speech, labile effect) and bulbar signs (tongue fasciculations) suggests the involvement of cranial nerves IX, X, and XII, which are not affected by cervical compression.

D) INCORRECT:

However, MS is characterized by isolated UMN dysfunction, not the mixed UMN and LMN dysfunction seen here. This patient's presentation is consistent with ALS, which is not associated with internuclear ophthalmoplegia.

This patient with ALS is at an increased risk for developing diaphragmatic paralysis and respiratory failure, which is the most common cause of death in individuals with ALS and requires prompt intervention. Noninvasive ventilation is the mainstay of management in patients with ALS and respiratory failure because it successfully compensates for the diaphragmatic dysfunction, provides symptomatic relief, improves quality of life, and increases survival rates. Disease-modifying drugs, such as riluzole and edaravone, should also be considered because they can slow down the functional decline and prolong survival in patients with ALS. Another severe complication of ALS is dysphagia, which can result in malnutrition, weight loss, and aspiration pneumonia and may require enteral nutrition support.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man is evaluated in the clinic for progressive muscle weakness over 8 months. He has difficulty lifting objects and has noticed occasional twitching in his arms. Examination shows muscle atrophy in the hands, fasciculations in the forearms, increased deep tendon reflexes in the lower extremities, and a bilateral extensor plantar response. Sensation is intact, and there are no bowel or bladder symptoms.
Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Multiple sclerosis causes demyelination in the central nervous system, leading to upper motor neuron signs like hyperreflexia. However, it does not cause lower motor neuron signs such as muscle atrophy and fasciculations. Additionally, multiple sclerosis typically presents with sensory disturbances or visual symptoms, which are absent here.

B) CORRECT:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) involves progressive degeneration of both upper and lower motor neurons. This patient exhibits lower motor neuron signs such as muscle atrophy and fasciculations, alongside upper motor neuron signs including hyperreflexia and a bilateral extensor plantar response. The intact sensation and absence of autonomic dysfunction help differentiate ALS from other neurological disorders. ALS pathophysiology includes abnormal protein aggregation and excitotoxicity, leading to neuronal loss. Electrophysiological studies often show denervation with compensatory reinnervation, confirming the dual motor neuron involvement.

Key learning point: The presence of both upper and lower motor neuron signs, such as brisk reflexes, spasticity, and fasciculations, is characteristic of motor neuron disease, such as Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS).

C) INCORRECT:

Spinal muscular atrophy involves degeneration of anterior horn cells, leading to lower motor neuron signs like muscle atrophy and fasciculations. However, it lacks upper motor neuron features such as hyperreflexia. It typically presents in infancy or childhood, not in middle-aged adults.

D) INCORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis affects the postsynaptic neuromuscular junction, presenting with fatigable weakness and often ocular symptoms. It does not involve upper motor neuron signs like hyperreflexia or lower motor neuron signs such as fasciculations. The progressive weakness without fluctuation or ocular involvement further distinguishes it from myasthenia gravis.

Patellar and ankle reflexes are 1+ on the right leg and 3+ on the left leg. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration is intact. Cranial nerve examination reveals fasciculations of the tongue. Mental status examination shows a labile affect and monotonous nasal speech. This patient with ALS is at an increased risk for developing diaphragmatic paralysis and respiratory failure, which is the most common cause of death in individuals with ALS and requires prompt intervention. Noninvasive ventilation is the mainstay of management in patients with ALS and respiratory failure because it successfully compensates for the diaphragmatic dysfunction, provides symptomatic relief, improves quality of life, and increases survival rates. Disease-modifying drugs, such as riluzole and edaravone, should also be considered because they can slow down the functional decline and prolong survival in patients with ALS. Another severe complication of ALS is dysphagia, which can result in malnutrition, weight loss, and aspiration pneumonia and may require enteral nutrition support.

Key learning point: Respiratory failure due to diaphragmatic paralysis is the most common and life-threatening complication of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

B) INCORRECT:

Cervical myelopathy is a common complication of cervical spine compression (e.g., in spondylosis, rheumatoid arthritis), which is characterized by findings of LMN injury at the level of the lesion and findings of UMN injury below the level of the lesion. Although this patient's hyperactive patellar and ankle reflexes are consistent with a cervical lesion, his upper extremities are not affected. Moreover, the presence of pseudobulbar palsy (monotonous nasal speech, labile effect) and bulbar signs (tongue fasciculations) suggests the involvement of cranial nerves IX, X, and XII, which are not affected by cervical compression.

C) INCORRECT:

Internuclear ophthalmoplegia can be seen in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS), which may manifest with slowly progressive weakness and hyperreflexia, both of which are seen in this patient. However, MS is characterized by isolated UMN dysfunction, not the mixed UMN and LMN dysfunction seen here. This patient's presentation is consistent with ALS, which is not associated with internuclear ophthalmoplegia.

D) INCORRECT:

Ascending paralysis is one of the hallmarks of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), which is characterized by rapidly progressive demyelination of the peripheral nerves and consequent LMN dysfunction. Although this patient has findings of LMN damage, he also shows signs of UMN damage, which would not be seen in GBS. Furthermore, muscle weakness in patients with GBS develops acutely (within days) and typically is symmetric and progresses upward, none of which is seen here. Finally, GBS symptoms usually occur after an episode of upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection and peak at 2–4 weeks after onset, neither of which is consistent with this patient's presentation.

E) INCORRECT:

Myasthenic crisis is an acute life-threatening complication of myasthenia gravis (MG), which is characterized by generalized muscle weakness that worsens throughout the day and during physical activity. Although this patient presents with muscular weakness, he has concurrent UMN signs, which are inconsistent with MG. In addition, EMG in patients with MG typically shows a decremental response following repetitive stimulation, whereas this patient's EMG shows spontaneous fasciculations. Finally, weakness in MG typically involves ocular muscles, manifesting with symptoms such as ptosis, diplopia, or blurred vision, none of which is reported by this patient.
questions.hint: This patient presents with progressive asymmetric muscle weakness and signs of both upper motor neuron (UMN) dysfunction (hyperreflexia, pseudobulbar palsy) and lower motor neuron (LMN) dysfunction (hyporeflexia, bulbar palsy). These findings, in conjunction with spontaneous fasciculation potentials on electromyography (EMG), are consistent with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

questions.text: You are caring for a 60-year-old man with a 1-year history of recurrent aspiration pneumonia who is brought to the emergency department by his daughter after she found him unconscious and gasping for air in bed. Despite resuscitative efforts, he dies. Autopsy reveals degeneration of the corticospinal tracts and anterior horn cells of the upper cervical cord, along with asymmetrical atrophy of the limb muscles, diaphragm, and intercostal muscles. Which one of the following drugs would have most likely slowed the progression of his condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glatiramer acetate is used in the treatment of patients with multiple sclerosis (MS), a demyelinating disease that causes upper motor neuron weakness and can subsequently result in respiratory failure. Autopsy would show focal demyelination of spinal cord tracts, loss of axons, and atrophy of oligodendrocytes (plaques); anterior horn cell degeneration would not be expected in patients with MS.

B) CORRECT:

ALS usually manifests in patients > 50 years old with a combination of symptoms of upper and lower motor neuron degeneration, including asymmetric limb weakness, fasciculations, cramps, and muscle stiffness. Symptoms of bulbar palsy, such as dysarthria as well as atrophy and fasciculations of the tongue, are early features of ALS in 25% of patients. Late symptoms include cognitive impairment as well as life-threatening conditions such as respiratory failure due to respiratory muscle paralysis and aspiration pneumonia due to bulbar weakness.

There is no definitive treatment for ALS. By blocking sodium channels, riluzole inhibits the excitotoxic effects of glutamate in the CNS and this effect slows down the deterioration of motor function in patients with ALS and thus increases life expectancy. Another medication used to slow the progression of ALS is edaravone (a free radical scavenger). The prognosis is generally very poor and most patients die within 3–5 years of symptom onset.

Key learning point: Riluzole slows progression and modestly prolongs survival in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis by inhibiting glutamate-mediated excitotoxicity in motor neurons.

C) INCORRECT:

Inactivated virus vaccines are used in the pre-exposure prophylaxis of certain viral infections, such as poliomyelitis or rabies. Polio causes motor weakness and atrophy due to neuron degeneration of the spinal cord (particularly the anterior horn cells). Symptoms can be severe and involve the diaphragm, causing respiratory failure, but would also involve fever, neck stiffness, vomiting, and muscle pain. In addition, polio is extremely rare since it has been eradicated from Canada and most other countries. Rabies usually presents first with flu-like symptoms and then progresses to encephalopathy, which can lead to respiratory failure if the respiratory center in the brainstem is involved. However, other symptoms would include hydrophobia, agitation, confusion, hallucinations, seizures, muscle rigidity, and hypersalivation. Autopsy would show Negri bodies in the brain, not alpha-motoneuron degeneration.

D) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are used to treat chronic, inflammatory diseases like systemic sclerosis, which can present with esophageal hypomotility (gastroesophageal reflux and aspiration pneumonia) and respiratory disease (and possible respiratory failure). Symptoms would also include cutaneous findings (e.g, thickening and hardening of the skin, sclerodactyly, calcinosis, Raynaud syndrome, telangiectasia) but not motor weakness or muscle atrophy. In addition, autopsy would show fibroblast proliferation and increased synthesis of normal collagen (inflammatory synthesis of extracellular matrix), not alpha-motoneuron degeneration.

E) INCORRECT:

Levodopa is used in the treatment of Parkinson disease, which can present with asymmetrical muscle atrophy. However, in Parkinson disease, autopsy would show neuron degeneration of the substantia nigra, not of the corticospinal tracts and anterior horn cells of the upper cervical cord. Moreover, respiratory failure is rare in Parkinson disease.
questions.hint: The autopsy findings of upper (corticospinal tract) and lower motor neuron (anterior horn cells, muscle atrophy) degeneration indicate amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 4-month history of progressive weakness in his right hand and slurred speech. His wife reports recently, his symptoms have worsened and he now has difficulty with fine motor tasks such as buttoning his shirt. On examination, he has asymmetric weakness and atrophy of the thenar eminence on the right, fasciculations in both arms, hyperreflexia in all extremities, and a positive Babinski sign bilaterally. His speech is dysarthric with visible tongue atrophy. Sensation is intact throughout. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ischemic stroke can present with acute weakness and dysarthria, but typically has a sudden onset rather than the 4-month progressive course described. Additionally, stroke would not typically cause the combination of upper motor neuron and lower motor neuron signs seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyponatremia can present with neurologic symptoms including weakness, seizures, and altered mental status. However, hyponatremia does not cause the characteristic combination of upper motor neuron and lower motor neuron signs seen in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has the classic presentation of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), with combined upper motor neuron (UMN) signs (hyperreflexia, positive Babinski sign) and lower motor neuron (LMN) signs (fasciculations, thenar atrophy). Asymmetric limb weakness beginning in the hands, bulbar involvement with dysarthria and tongue atrophy, and preserved sensation are characteristic features. The progressive disease course over months and the presence of both UMN and LMN signs strongly suggest ALS.

D) INCORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis typically manifests with fatigable weakness of skeletal muscles that worsens with increased muscle use and improves with rest. It does not manifest with upper or lower motor neuron signs such as fasciculations, hyperreflexia, or Babinski sign.

E) INCORRECT:

Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome manifests with proximal muscle weakness that improves with repetitive stimulation and symptoms of autonomic dysfunction. It does not cause the motor neuron signs seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) presents to the emergency department with worsening dyspnea. ALS was diagnosed 3 years ago and he has since had a progressive course with worsening weakness that now involves all 4 extremities. Over the past 2 weeks, he has experienced increasing shortness of breath, orthopnea, and morning headaches. He is alert and oriented. He states that he is aware of the progressive nature of his disease and that he is interested in comfort-focused care. His main goal is to be able to attend his son's wedding in two weeks. Vital signs are BP, 135/82; P, 96; R, 26; T, 37.1°C; O₂ sat 88% on room air. He appears fatigued, with shallow respirations and use of accessory muscles. His lungs are clear to auscultation. Recent PFTs showed vital capacity of 75% predicted. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High-flow nasal cannula provides supplemental oxygen, but it does not address the underlying ventilatory failure from progressive respiratory muscle weakness.

B) INCORRECT:

Bronchopulmonary hygiene measures may provide some benefit as adjunctive therapy, but they are not sufficient to address this patient's ventilatory failure from progressive respiratory muscle weakness.

C) INCORRECT:

Intubation is overly aggressive given this patient’s comfort-focused care preferences and his ability to cooperate with noninvasive measures.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient has clear indications for considering noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation (NIPPV), including signs of respiratory muscle weakness (orthopnea, morning headaches, accessory muscle use), hypoxemia, and declining pulmonary function (VC < 80% of the predicted value). NIPPV aligns with his comfort-focused care preferences because it is a noninvasive intervention that may improve symptoms and quality of life, potentially allowing him to achieve his goal of attending the wedding.

E) INCORRECT:

Morphine can provide symptomatic relief for dyspnea, but does not address the potentially treatable respiratory failure. Given this patient’s specific functional goal and the availability of another intervention that can help him achieve it, symptomatic management alone is premature.
